array.string: Stono Rebellion, the largest slave uprising in Britains mainland North American colonies prior to the American Revolution, erupts near Charleston, South Carolina.
Great Britain passes the Sugar Act doubling the duties on foreign goods reshipped from England to the colonies

The Currency Act prohibiting the colonists from issuing any legal tender paper money The Currency Act prohibiting the colonists from issuing any legal tender paper moneyThe Currency Act prohibiting the colonists from issuing any legal tender paper money
Great Britain passes the Stamp Act, granting and applying certain stamp duties, and other duties, in the British colonies.
Great Britain passes the Quartering Act that requires the 13 American colonies to house British troops.
The Virginia Stamp Act: claiming that only the Virginia assembly can legally tax Virginia residents
The British Parliament repeals the Stamp Act, which was very unpopular in the British colonies.
Boston Massacre: Five Americans are killed by British troops.
Samuel Adams and Joseph Warren form the first Committee of Correspondence.
The Tea Act: Unsold tea from east India Company was to be sold in the colonies.
Boston Tea Party: Members of the Sons of Liberty dump tea into Boston harbor as a protest against the Tea Act.
The Kingdom of Great Britain orders the port of Boston, Massachusetts closed in the Boston Port Act.
British Parliament declares Massachusetts in rebellion.
Patrick Henry delivers his famous speech -"give me liberty or give me death" at St. John's Church in Richmond, Virginia.
British troops and local militia of Massachusetts fire the first shots of the American Revolution at Lexington.
the siege of Boston begins, which followed the first battles at Lexington and Concord.
Ethan Allen and Benedict Arnold lead the capture Fort Ticonderoga.
The Continental Congress bans trade with Canada.
British general Thomas Gage declares martial law in Massachusetts.
The United States Army is established by the Continental Congress.
George Washington is appointed commander-in-chief of the Continental Army.
Battle of Bunker Hill: British forces take Breed's Hill outside of Boston with heavy casualties.
George Washington takes command of the Continental Army at Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The Continental Congress passes a resolution creating the Continental Marines.
Battle of Quebec British forces repulse an attack by Continental Army generals Richard Montgomery and Benedict Arnold.
British forces evacuate Boston, Massachusetts after George Washington and Henry Knox place artillery overlooking the city.
Virginia convention instructs its delegates to propose a declaration of independence from Great Britain.
Battle of Trois-Rivières - American invaders are driven back at Trois-Rivière, Quebec.
The Continental Congress approves a Declaration of Independence from the Kingdom of Great Britain.
British-American peace conference on Staten Island fails to stop nascent American Revolution.
British land at Kip's Bay during the New York Campaign.
the Battle of Harlem Heights is fought.
Nathan Hale is hanged for spying during American Revolution.
Battle of Valcour Island - On Lake Champlain 15 American gunboats are defeated but give Patriot forces enough time to prepare defenses of New York City.
Battle of White Plains - British Army forces arrive at White Plains, attack and capture Chatterton Hill from the Americans.
Hessian mercenaries capture Fort Washington from the Patriots.
The British are defeated in the Battle of Trenton.
New Connecticut (present day Vermont) declares its independence.
Marquis de Lafayette lands near Charleston, South Carolina, in order to help the Continental Congress to train its army.
Battle of Ticonderoga: Due to a bombardment by British artillery under General John Burgoyne, American forces retreat from Fort Ticonderoga, New York.
Battle of Bennington - British forces are defeated by American troops.
Cooch's Bridge - Skirmish of American Revolutionary war in New Castle County, Delaware where the Flag of the United States was flown in battle for the first time.
Battle of Brandywine - Major American Revolutionary war victory for British in Chester County, Pennsylvania.
British troops occupy Philadelphia during the American Revolution.
Americans beat the British in the Battle of Second Saratoga and the Battle of Bemis Heights.
After 16 months of debate the Continental Congress approves the Articles of Confederation.
George Washington's Continental Army goes into winter quarters at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania.
In Paris the Treaty of Alliance and the Treaty of Amity and Commerce are signed by the United States and France signaling official recognition of the new republic.
Baron von Steuben arrives at Valley Forge, Pennsylvania to help to train the Continental Army.
Battle of Monmouth fought between the American Continental Army under George Washington and the British Army led by Sir Henry Clinton.
British forces massacre 360 men, women & children in the Wyoming Valley massacre.
Louis XVI of France declares war on the Kingdom of Great Britain.
First Battle of Ushant - British and French fleets fight to a standoff.
Benedict Arnold is court-martialed for malfeasance in his treatment of government property.
United States forces led by General Anthony Wayne capture Stony Point, New York from British troops.
USS Bonhomme Richard, commanded by John Paul Jones, wins a fight against the British ships of war Serapis and Countess of Scarborough off the coast of England.
Samuel Huntington is elected President of the Continental Congress, succeeding John Jay.
Charleston, South Carolina is taken by British forces.
Battle of Camden - The British defeat the Americans near Camden, South Carolina.
Benedict Arnold gives the British the plans to West Point.
British Major John Andre arrested as a spy by American soldiers exposing Benedict Arnold's treason.
Battle of Kings Mountain American Patriot militia defeat Loyalist irregulars led by British colonel Patrick Ferguson in South Carolina.
Royalton, Vermont and Tunbridge, Vermont last major raid of the American Revolutionary War
Richmond, Virginia is burned by British naval forces led by Benedict Arnold.
Battle of Guilford Courthouse - Near present-day Greensboro, North Carolina, 1,900 British troops under General Charles Cornwallis defeat an American force numbering 4,400.
American forces backed by a French fleet begin the siege of Yorktown, Virginia.
General Charles Cornwallis offers his surrender to the American revolutionaries at Yorktown, Virginia.
At Yorktown, Virginia, British General Lord Cornwallis surrenders 8,000 British soldiers and seamen to a larger Franco-American force, effectively bringing an end to the American Revolution.
Second Battle of Ushant - A Royal Navy squadron, commanded by Rear Admiral Richard Kempenfelt in HMS Victory, defeats a French fleet.
Battle of Blue Licks: the last major battle of the American Revolutionary War, almost ten months after the surrender of the British commander Lord Cornwallis following the Siege of Yorktown.
In Paris, representatives from the United States and the Kingdom of Great Britain sign preliminary peace articles (later formalized in the 1783 Treaty of Paris).
The United Kingdom formally declares that it will cease hostilities with the United States of America.
The war ends with the signing of the Treaty of Paris by the United States and the Kingdom of Great Britain.
The last British troops leave New York City three months after the signing of the Treaty of Paris.
The United States ratifies a peace treaty with England.
